scenario:
Walmart (WMT) and Costco (COST) are both recession-resistant retailers with strong growth prospects. Walmart's scale enables it to sell products at lower prices, while Costco's warehouse stores lock in shoppers with bulk discounts and sticky membership plans. 

Walmart operates over 10,600 stores and warehouse clubs worldwide, with 80% of revenue generated from its U.S. stores. Costco operates 897 warehouses, with 617 locations in the U.S. and Puerto Rico. 

Walmart's revenue rose 7% in fiscal 2024, driven by 5.6% U.S. comps and 13% international revenue growth. Analysts expect Walmart's revenue and earnings per share (EPS) to grow at a compound annual growth rate (CAGR) of 5% and 17%, respectively, from fiscal 2024 to fiscal 2027. 

Costco's revenue rose 17% in fiscal 2021, driven by the pandemic, and 5% in fiscal 2024. Analysts expect Costco's revenue and EPS to grow at a CAGR of 7% and 11%, respectively, from fiscal 2024 to fiscal 2027. 

Walmart's stock is historically expensive at 34 times next year's earnings, while Costco's stock is also expensive at 47 times next year's earnings. Both stocks have low forward dividend yields of 1% and 0.5%, respectively. 

Walmart is considered the better buy due to its more diversified business, lower dependence on recurring memberships, and cheaper stock.
